description: Define database schemas using Python classes and query data effortlessly.

slides.title: What is a Model?
slides.content:
# Blueprint üó∫Ô∏è

A Model is the single, definitive source of information about your data.

It contains the essential fields and behaviors of the data you‚Äôre storing.

Usually, each model maps to a single database table.

slides.title: Defining a Model
slides.content:
# Python Classes üêç

In `models.py`:

<!-- FULL_CODE_START
from django.db import models

class Person(models.Model):
    first_name = models.CharField(max_length=30)
    last_name = models.CharField(max_length=30)
FULL_CODE_END -->

This creates a `myapp_person` table.

slides.title: Migrations
slides.content:
# Propagate Changes üåä

1. **Make Changes:** Edit `models.py`.
2. **Create Migrations:** `python manage.py makemigrations` (Creates a script of changes).
3. **Apply Migrations:** `python manage.py migrate` (Runs the script on DB).

slides.title: Field Types
slides.content:
# Data Types üóÉÔ∏è

- `CharField`: Small text.
- `TextField`: Large text.
- `IntegerField`: Numbers.
- `DateTimeField`: Dates & times.
- `BooleanField`: True/False.
- `EmailField`: Validates email.

slides.title: Relationships
slides.content:
# Connecting Tables üîó

- **ForeignKey:** 1-to-many (e.g., Author has many Books).
- **ManyToManyField:** Many-to-many (e.g., Pizza toppings).
- **OneToOneField:** 1-to-1 (e.g., User Profile).

slides.title: Relation Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Which field type would you use to link a 'Comment' to a specific 'Post' so that one post can have many comments?

slides.title: The ORM
slides.content:
# No SQL Needed üö´

Django's **Object-Relational Mapper** lets you interact with the DB using Python code.

`Entry.objects.all()` instead of `SELECT * FROM blog_entry;`.

slides.title: Creating Objects
slides.content:
# Insert Data üíæ

<!-- FULL_CODE_START
# Method 1
p = Person(first_name="John", last_name="Doe")
p.save()

# Method 2
Person.objects.create(first_name="Jane", last_name="Doe")
FULL_CODE_END -->

slides.title: Querying Objects
slides.content:
# Retrieve Data üîé

- `Person.objects.all()`: Get everyone.
- `Person.objects.get(id=1)`: Get one (error if multiple/none).
- `Person.objects.filter(last_name='Doe')`: Get all Does.

slides.title: Updating & Deleting
slides.content:
# Modify Data ‚úèÔ∏è

<!-- FULL_CODE_START
# Update
p = Person.objects.get(id=1)
p.first_name = 'Johnny'
p.save()

# Delete
p.delete()
FULL_CODE_END -->

slides.title: Meta Options
slides.content:
# Fine Tuning üéõÔ∏è

Use the `Meta` inner class.

<!-- FULL_CODE_START
class Person(models.Model):
    # fields...
    class Meta:
        ordering = ['last_name']
        verbose_name_plural = "People"
FULL_CODE_END -->

slides.title: Migration Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: What is the primary purpose of `makemigrations`?
quizOptions: To apply changes to the database immediately
To create a Python file describing changes to your models

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Recap: Models üß±

Data Structure.

- **Class:** Maps to Table.
- **Fields:** Map to Columns.
- **Migrations:** Version control for DB.
- **ORM:** Pythonic database access.
